question: Two rods, one of copper (Cu) and the other of iron (Fe) having initial lengths L1 and L2 respectively are connected together to form a single rod of length L1+L2. The coefficient of linear expansion of Cu and Fe are alpha_c and alpha_i respectively. If the length of each rod increase by the same amount when their temperatures are raised by t°C, then ratio of (L1 - L2) / (L1 + L2) will be [MHT-CET 2024]
question_latex: Two rods, one of copper (Cu) and the other of iron (Fe) having initial lengths $L_{1}$ and $L_{2}$ respectively are connected together to form a single rod of length $L_{1}+L_{2}$. The coefficient of linear expansion of Cu and Fe are $\alpha_{c}$ and $\alpha_{i}$ respectively. If the length of each rod increase by the same amount when their temperatures are raised by $t^{\circ}C$, then ratio of $\frac{L_{1}-L_{2}}{L_{1}+L_{2}}$ will be [MHT-CET 2024]
solution: Given $\Delta L_{1} = \Delta L_{2} \Rightarrow L_{1}\alpha_{c}\Delta\theta = L_{2}\alpha_{i}\Delta\theta$. Thus $L_{1}\alpha_{c} = L_{2}\alpha_{i} \Rightarrow \frac{L_{1}}{L_{2}} = \frac{\alpha_{i}}{\alpha_{c}}$. By components and dividends: $\frac{L_{1}-L_{2}}{L_{1}+L_{2}} = \frac{\alpha_{i}-\alpha_{c}}{\alpha_{i}+\alpha_{c}}$.

question: A cylindrical metallic rod in thermal contact with two reservoirs of heat at its two ends conduct an amount of heat 'Q1' in time 't'. The metallic rod is melted and the material is formed into a rod having length four times that of the original rod. The amount of heat conducted by the new rod, placed in thermal contact with the same two reservoirs for time 't' is 'Q2'. The change in heat conducted (Q1 - Q2) is [MHT-CET 2023]
question_latex: A cylindrical metallic rod in thermal contact with two reservoirs of heat at its two ends conduct an amount of heat '$Q_{1}$' in time '$t$'. The metallic rod is melted and the material is formed into a rod having length four times that of the original rod. The amount of heat conducted by the new rod, placed in thermal contact with the same two reservoirs for time '$t$' is '$Q_{2}$'. The change in heat conducted ($Q_{1}-Q_{2}$) is [MHT-CET 2023]
solution: $Q = \frac{KA\Delta T t}{L}$. Since volume is constant, $A_{1}L_{1} = A_{2}L_{2} \Rightarrow A_{2} = A_{1}/4$ if $L_{2} = 4L_{1}$. $Q_{2} = \frac{K(A_{1}/4)\Delta T t}{4L_{1}} = \frac{Q_{1}}{16}$. Change $= Q_{1} - Q_{1}/16 = 15Q_{1}/16$.

question: A sphere of aluminium of 0.05 kg placed in a vessel containing boiling water for sufficient time then it traustered to 0.15 kg calorimeter containing 0.25 kg of water at 20°C. The temperature of water rises and attains a steady state at 23°C, then what will be the specific heat capacity of aluminium? (Given specific heat of copper = 386 J/kgK)
question_latex: A sphere of aluminium of $0.05$ kg placed in a vessel containing boiling water for sufficient time then it traustered to $0.15$ kg calorimeter containing $0.25$ kg of water at $20^{\circ}C$. The temperature of water rises and attains a steady state at $23^{\circ}C$, then what will be the specific heat capacity of aluminium? (Given specific heat of copper $= 386~J/kgK$)
solution: Heat lost by Al = Heat gained by (water + calorimeter). $m_{Al}s_{Al}(100-23) = m_{w}s_{w}(23-20) + m_{c}s_{c}(23-20)$. $0.05 \times s_{Al} \times 77 = 0.25 \times 4200 \times 3 + 0.15 \times 386 \times 3 \Rightarrow 3.85 s_{Al} = 3150 + 173.7 \Rightarrow s_{Al} = 863.3~J/kgK$.

question: Advantage of gas thermometer is, it can measure temperature accurately and it is more sensitive because
question_latex: Advantage of gas thermometer is, it can measure temperature accurately and it is more sensitive because
options: A. Coefficient of expansion of a gas is very low and thermal capacity is very large.
B. Coefficient of expansion of gas is very large and its thermal capacity is very low.
C. Co-efficient of expansion of a gas is very large as well its thermal capacity is large.
D. Coefficient of expansion of a gas is very low as well as its thermal capacity is low.
solution: Gases expand significantly for small temperature changes and have low specific heat, making them highly sensitive.

question: A metal rod of length L and cross-sectional area A is heated through T°C. What is the force required to prevent the expansion of the rod lengthwise? (Y = Young's modulus of material of the rod, alpha = coefficient of linear expansion of the rod.)
question_latex: A metal rod of length $L$ and cross-sectional area $A$ is heated through $T^{\circ}C$. What is the force required to prevent the expansion of the rod lengthwise? ($Y = $ Young's modulus of material of the rod, $\alpha = $ coefficient of linear expansion of the rod.)
options: A. YA alpha T / (1 - alpha T)
B. YA alpha T / (1 + alpha T)
C. YA alpha / T(1 + alpha T)
solution: $\Delta L = L_{0}\alpha T$. New length $L = L_{0}(1+\alpha T)$. Thermal stress $= Y \frac{\Delta L}{L}$. Force $F = Stress \times Area = YA \frac{L_{0}\alpha T}{L_{0}(1+\alpha T)} = \frac{YA\alpha T}{1+\alpha T}$.

question: A wall has two layers A and B each made of a different material. Both the layers have the same thickness. The thermal conductivity of the material of A is twice that of B. Under thermal equillibrium, the temperature difference across the wall is 36°C. The temperature difference across the layer A is:
question_latex: A wall has two layers A and B each made of a different material. Both the layers have the same thickness. The thermal conductivity of the material of A is twice that of B. Under thermal equillibrium, the temperature difference across the wall is $36^{\circ}C$. The temperature difference across the layer A is:
solution: $Q/t$ is same. $K_{A}\Delta T_{A} = K_{B}\Delta T_{B} \Rightarrow 2K_{B}\Delta T_{A} = K_{B}\Delta T_{B} \Rightarrow \Delta T_{B} = 2\Delta T_{A}$. Since $\Delta T_{A} + \Delta T_{B} = 36 \Rightarrow 3\Delta T_{A} = 36 \Rightarrow \Delta T_{A} = 12^{\circ}C$.

question: Which one of the following specifications would you select for the material to make fuse wire?

C. greater specific heat, greater melting point
D. less specific heat, greater melting point
solution: Low specific heat ensures it heats up quickly, and low melting point ensures it breaks early during current surges.

question: The pressure reading in a thermometer at steam point is 1.5 x 10^3 Pa. What is the pressure reading at triple point knowing the linear relationship between temperature and pressure?
question_latex: The pressure reading in a thermometer at steam point is $1.5\times10^{3}$ Pa. What is the pressure reading at triple point knowing the linear relationship between temperature and pressure?
solution: $P \propto T$. $P_{steam}/P_{triple} = 373.15 / 273.16 \Rightarrow P_{triple} = 1.5 \times 10^{3} \times (273.16 / 373.15) \approx 1.1 \times 10^{3} Pa$. (Closest option is D).

question: Two uniform brass rods A and B of length 'l' and '2l' and their radii '2 r' and 'r' respectively are heated to same temperature. The ratio of the increases in the volume of rod A to that of rod B is [MHT-CET 2023]
question_latex: Two uniform brass rods A and B of length '$l$' and '$2l$' and their radii '$2r$' and '$r$' respectively are heated to same temperature. The ratio of the increases in the volume of rod A to that of rod B is [MHT-CET 2023]
solution: $\Delta V = V_{i}\gamma\Delta T$. Ratio $\Delta V_{A} / \Delta V_{B} = V_{A} / V_{B} = (\pi(2r)^{2}l) / (\pi r^{2}(2l)) = 4 / 2 = 2$.

question: A composite rod is made by joining two different materials of lengths l1 and l2 Their co-efficient of linear expansion is alpha1 and alpha2 respectively, then what will be the co-efficient of linear expansion of composite rod when its temperature changes from t1°C to t2°C?
question_latex: A composite rod is made by joining two different materials of lengths $l_{1}$ and $l_{2}$ Their co-efficient of linear expansion is $\alpha_{1}$ and $\alpha_{2}$ respectively, then what will be the co-efficient of linear expansion of composite rod when its temperature changes from $t_{1}^{\circ}C$ to $t_{2}^{\circ}C$?
solution: Total expansion $\Delta L = (l_{1}+l_{2})\alpha_{c}\Delta T = l_{1}\alpha_{1}\Delta T + l_{2}\alpha_{2}\Delta T \Rightarrow \alpha_{c} = \frac{l_{1}\alpha_{1} + l_{2}\alpha_{2}}{l_{1} + l_{2}}$.

question: The time rate of heat flow 'Q/t' through a metal rod of length, area of cross section 'A' and thermal conductivity 'K' is given by where T1 and T2 is the temperature (T1 > T2) and RT is the thermal resistance. question_latex: The time rate of heat flow '$Q/t$' through a metal rod of length, area of cross section '$A$' and thermal conductivity '$K$' is given by where $T_{1}$ and $T_{2}$ is the temperature ($T_{1}>T_{2}$) and $R_{T}$ is the thermal resistance. The value of thermal resistance of the rod in terms of '$x$', '$A$' and '$K$' is [2025]
solution: $R_{T} = \frac{L}{KA}$. Here length is $x$, so $R_{T} = x / KA$.

question: A body cools from 80°C to 50°C in 5 min. In the next time of 't' in, the body continues to cool from 50°C to 30°C. The total time taken by the body to cool from 80°C to 30°C is [The temperature of the surroundings is 20°C.] [2025]
question_latex: A body cools from $80^{\circ}C$ to $50^{\circ}C$ in $5$ min. In the next time of '$t$' in, the body continues to cool from $50^{\circ}C$ to $30^{\circ}C$. The total time taken by the body to cool from $80^{\circ}C$ to $30^{\circ}C$ is [The temperature of the surroundings is $20^{\circ}C$.] [2025]
solution: Newton's law: $(80-50)/5 = K(65-20) \Rightarrow 6 = 45 K \Rightarrow K = 6/45 = 2/15$. For next step: $(50-30)/t = K(40-20) \Rightarrow 20/t = 20 K \Rightarrow 1/t = K = 2/15 \Rightarrow t = 7.5$ min. Total time $= 5 + 7.5 = 12.5$ min.

question: The ratio of thermal conductivity of two rods A and B of different materials is 5:4. The two rods of same area of cross-section and same thermal resistance will have the lengths in the ration (A to B) [MHT-CET 2023]
question_latex: The ratio of thermal conductivity of two rods A and B of different materials is $5:4$. The two rods of same area of cross-section and same thermal resistance will have the lengths in the ration (A to B) [MHT-CET 2023]
solution: $R_{T} = L / (KA)$. If $R_{T}$ and $A$ are same, $L \propto K$. Ratio $L_{A} : L_{B} = K_{A} : K_{B} = 5 : 4$.

question: What can be length of steel rod and copper rod so that length of steel rod is 5 cm longer than the copper rod at all temperatures? (alpha_c = 17 x 10^-6/°C and alpha_s = 11 x 10^-6/°C)
question_latex: What can be length of steel rod and copper rod so that length of steel rod is $5$ cm longer than the copper rod at all temperatures? ($\alpha_{c}=17\times10^{-6}/^{\circ}C$ and $\alpha_{s}=11\times10^{-6}/^{\circ}C$)
solution: Constant difference $\Rightarrow \Delta L_{s} = \Delta L_{c} \Rightarrow L_{s}\alpha_{s} = L_{c}\alpha_{c}$. Also $L_{s} - L_{c} = 5$. $L_{c} = L_{s}(11/17)$. $L_{s} - 11/17 L_{s} = 5 \Rightarrow 6/17 L_{s} = 5 \Rightarrow L_{s} = 85/6 = 14.17$ cm. $L_{c} = 9.17$ cm.

question: Two identical iron are connected in parallel between two vessels, one containing boiling water and the other containing ice. The ice melts at the rate of q1 gram/s. When the rods are welded end to end and connected to the same vessels, the rate of melting of ice of q2 gram/s. What will be the ratio q1 / q2?
question_latex: Two identical iron are connected in parallel between two vessels, one containing boiling water and the other containing ice. The ice melts at the rate of $q_{1}~gram/s$. When the rods are welded end to end and connected to the same vessels, the rate of melting of ice of $q_{2}~gram/s$. What will be the ratio $\frac{q_{1}}{q_{2}}$?
solution: Parallel: $H_{1} \propto (2A)/L = 2(A/L)$. Series: $H_{2} \propto A/(2L) = 0.5(A/L)$. Ratio $H_{1}/H_{2} = 2/0.5 = 4$. Rate of melting is proportional to heat flow.

question: A bucket full of hot water is kept in a room and it cools from 75°C to 70°C in T1 minutes, from 70°C to 65°C in T2 minutes and from 65°C to 60°C in T3 minutes, then [MHT-CET 2023]
question_latex: A bucket full of hot water is kept in a room and it cools from $75^{\circ}C$ to $70^{\circ}C$ in $T_{1}$ minutes, from $70^{\circ}C$ to $65^{\circ}C$ in $T_{2}$ minutes and from $65^{\circ}C$ to $60^{\circ}C$ in $T_{3}$ minutes, then [MHT-CET 2023]
solution: Newton's law states rate of cooling decreases as temperature difference decreases, so time taken increases.

question: A stationary object at 4°C and weighing 3.5 kg falls from a height of 2000 m on snow mountain at 0°C. If the temperature of the object just before hitting the snow is 0°C and the object comes to rest immediately then the quantity of ice that melts is (Acceleration due to gravity = 10 m/s^2, Latent heat of ice = 3.5 x 10^5 J/kg) [2025]
question_latex: A stationary object at $4^{\circ}C$ and weighing $3.5$ kg falls from a height of $2000$ m on snow mountain at $0^{\circ}C$. If the temperature of the object just before hitting the snow is $0^{\circ}C$ and the object comes to rest immediately then the quantity of ice that melts is (Acceleration due to gravity $= 10~m/s^{2}$, Latent heat of ice $= 3.5\times10^{5}J/kg$) [2025]
solution: Energy lost $= Mgh + Mc\Delta T = 3.5 \times 10 \times 2000 + 3.5 \times c \times 4$. (Given object at 0C just before hit, so only PE is used). Energy $= 70000$ J. $m L_{f} = 70000 \Rightarrow m = 70000 / (3.5 \times 10^{5}) = 0.2$ kg $= 200$ g.

question: The temperature of an air bubble while rising from bottom to surface of a lake remains constant but diameter is doubled. If pressure on the surface is h meter of mercury column and relative density of mercury is ' p' then the depth of the lake is [2025]
question_latex: The temperature of an air bubble while rising from bottom to surface of a lake remains constant but diameter is doubled. If pressure on the surface is $h$ meter of mercury column and relative density of mercury is '$p$' then the depth of the lake is [2025]
solution: Diameter double $\Rightarrow V_{2} = 8 V_{1}$. Constant T $\Rightarrow P_{1}V_{1} = P_{2}V_{2} \Rightarrow P_{1} = 8 P_{2}$. $P_{2} = P_{atm} = \rho_{Hg}gh$. $P_{1} = P_{atm} + \rho_{w}gD$. $8\rho_{Hg}gh = \rho_{Hg}gh + \rho_{w}gD \Rightarrow 7\rho_{Hg}gh = \rho_{w}gD \Rightarrow D = 7 h (\rho_{Hg}/\rho_{w}) = 7hp$.

question: A black rectangular surface of area 'A' emits energy 'E' per second at 27°C. If length and breadth is reduced to (1/3)^rd of its initial value and temperature is raised to 327°C then energy emitted per second becomes [MHT-CET 2021]
question_latex: A black rectangular surface of area '$A$' emits energy '$E$' per second at $27^{\circ}C$. If length and breadth is reduced to $(1/3)^{rd}$ of its initial value and temperature is raised to $327^{\circ}C$ then energy emitted per second becomes [MHT-CET 2021]
solution: $E = \sigma A T^{4}$. New Area $A' = A/9$. New Temp $T' = 600 K = 2T$. $E' = \sigma (A/9) (2T)^{4} = 16/9 \sigma A T^{4} = 16E / 9$.

question: A hole is drilled in a copper sheet. The diameter of the hole is 4.24 cm at 27.0°C. What is the change in the diameter of the hole when the sheet is heated to 227°C: Coefficient of linear expansion of copper = 1.70 x 10^-5 K^-1
question_latex: A hole is drilled in a copper sheet. The diameter of the hole is $4.24$ cm at $27.0^{\circ}C$. What is the change in the diameter of the hole when the sheet is heated to $227^{\circ}C:$ Coefficient of linear expansion of copper $= 1.70 \times 10^{-5} K^{-1}$
solution: Diameter expands just like a solid rod. $\Delta d = d\alpha\Delta T = 4.24 \times 1.7 \times 10^{-5} \times 200 = 0.0144$ cm.

question_latex: The size of one degree on celsius scale is $x$ and that on fahrenheit scale is $y$, then choose correct statement.
solution: 100 Celsius degrees = 180 Fahrenheit degrees. So 1 Celsius degree = 1.8 Fahrenheit degrees. $x = 1.8y$.

question: Rate of flow of heat through a cylindrical rod is ' H1 '. The temperatures of the ends of the rod are ' T1 ' and ' T2 '. If all the dimensions of the rod are doubled and the temperature difference remains the same, the rate of flow of heat becomes ' H2 '. Then [MHT-CET 2022]

question: Two rods of lengths 'l1' and ' l2' are made of materials whose coefficients of linear expansion ' alpha1' ' alpha2 ' respectively. If the difference between their lengths is independent of temperature, then l1 / l2 is [MHT-CET 2024]
question_latex: Two rods of lengths '$l_{1}$' and '$l_{2}$' are made of materials whose coefficients of linear expansion '$\alpha_{1}$' '$\alpha_{2}$' respectively. If the difference between their lengths is independent of temperature, then $\frac{l_{1}}{l_{2}}$ is [MHT-CET 2024]
solution: $\Delta L = (l_{1}\alpha_{1} - l_{2}\alpha_{2})\Delta T$. For this to be zero, $l_{1}\alpha_{1} = l_{2}\alpha_{2} \Rightarrow l_{1}/l_{2} = \alpha_{2}/\alpha_{1}$.

question: Two rods P and Q have equal lengths. Their thermal conductivities are K1 and K2 and cross sectional area are A1 and A2. When the temperature at ends of each rod are T1 and T2 respectively, the rate of flow of heat through P and Q will be equal if [MHT-CET 2022]
question_latex: Two rods P and Q have equal lengths. Their thermal conductivities are $K_{1}$ and $K_{2}$ and cross sectional area are $A_{1}$ and $A_{2}$. When the temperature at ends of each rod are $T_{1}$ and $T_{2}$ respectively, the rate of flow of heat through P and Q will be equal if [MHT-CET 2022]
options: B. A1 / A2 = K2 / K1 x T2 / T1
solution: $Q/t = KA\Delta T / L$. If $L, \Delta T, Q/t$ are same, $K_{1}A_{1} = K_{2}A_{2} \Rightarrow A_{1}/A_{2} = K_{2}/K_{1}$.

question: Convection mostly takes place in_
question_latex: Convection mostly takes place in_

question: A copper rod and a steel rod having the same area of cross-section are joined end to end. The free end of the copper road is at 100°C and free end of the steel road is at 0°C. Calculate the temperature at their junction if Kcopper = 9Ksteel and length of copper road = 3 length of steel rod.
question_latex: A copper rod and a steel rod having the same area of cross-section are joined end to end. The free end of the copper road is at $100^{\circ}C$ and free end of the steel road is at $0^{\circ}C.$ Calculate the temperature at their junction if $K_{copper}=9K_{steel}$ and length of copper road $=3$ length of steel rod.
solution: Steady state: $Q/t$ is same. $K_{c}A(100-T)/L_{c} = K_{s}A(T-0)/L_{s}$. $9K_{s}(100-T)/(3L_{s}) = K_{s}T/L_{s} \Rightarrow 3(100-T) = T \Rightarrow 300 - 3T = T \Rightarrow 4T = 300 \Rightarrow T = 75^{\circ}C$.

question_latex: The CGS unit of heat energy is

question: The ratio of thermal conductivity of two rods A and B having same area of cross-section is 3:2. If the thermal resistance of two rods is same, then the ratio of length of rod A to length of rod B is [MHT-CET 2022]
question_latex: The ratio of thermal conductivity of two rods A and B having same area of cross-section is $3:2$. If the thermal resistance of two rods is same, then the ratio of length of rod A to length of rod B is [MHT-CET 2022]
solution: $R_{T} = L / (KA)$. If $R_{T}$ and $A$ are same, $L \propto K$. Ratio $3 : 2$.

question: One end of a thermally insulted rod is kept at temperature T1 and the other end at ' T2. The rod is composed of two sections of lengths ' l1 and ' l2' having thermal conductivities' K1 ' and ' K2 ' respectively. The temperature 'T' at the interface of the sections is [MHT-CET 2021]

The rod is composed of two sections of lengths '$l_{1}$ and '$l_{2}$' having thermal conductivities'$K_{1}$' and '$K_{2}$' respectively. The temperature 'T' at the interface of the sections is [MHT-CET 2021]
solution: Duplicate of 333 (with T instead of theta). $T = \frac{K_{1}T_{1}l_{2} + K_{2}T_{2}l_{1}}{K_{1}l_{2} + K_{2}l_{1}}$.
